title: Congressman Trey Gowdy and five movie villains he looks like
text:
Susan Walsh/AP Benghazi Chairman Representative Trey Gowdy, R-S.C. has a reputation for being tough-minded. Benghazi Committee Chairman and Tea Party member Trey Gowdy is known for being a no-nonsense kind of man — but now he’s being likened on social media to a variety of scary movie characters.
The South Carolina congressman is already known for not holding back his thoughts. He told Hillary Clinton last weekend that she was “ not worth 18 months ” of his life when responding to critics who claimed his investigation into the Benghazi attacks was a political effort to go after the former Secretary of State.
THE MANY FACES OF HILLARY CLINTON DURING BENGHAZI HEARING
But now social media users are poking fun at him, and comparing his likeness to famous characters in popular films.
Here is a list of five characters who resemble the politician:
Lord Voldemort of the “Harry Potter” movies
J. Scott Applewhite/AP Both Trey Gowdy and Lord Voldemort seek respect. Enlarge Courtesy of Warner Bros. Picture/Courtesy of Warner Bros. Enterta RALPH FIENNES as Lord Voldemort in Warner Bros. Pictures' fantasy "Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix.” PHOTOGRAPHS TO BE USED SOLELY FOR ADVERTISING, PROMOTION, PUBLICITY OR REVIEWS OF THIS SPECIFIC MOTION PICTURE AND TO REMAIN THE PROPERTY OF THE STUDIO. NOT FOR SALE OR REDISTRIBUTION Enlarge Both Trey Gowdy and Lord Voldemort seek respect.
The familiar pensive, yet sniveling look on Lord Voldemort’s face may be a reminder of Trey Gowdy’s expression in various situations of duress during media interviews.
Draco Malfoy of the “Harry Potter” movies
Cliff Owen/AP Gowdy and "Harry Potter" character Draco Malfoy could be long-lost brothers. Enlarge Jaap Buitendijk/AP In this film publicity image released by Warner Bros. Pictures, from left, Josh Herdman portrays Gregory Goyle, Tom Felton portrays Draco Malfoy and Louis Cordice portrays Blaise Zabini in a scene from "Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows: Part 2." (AP Photo/Warner Bros. Pictures, Jaap Buitendijk) Enlarge Gowdy and "Harry Potter" character Draco Malfoy could be long-lost brothers.
Gowdy’s slick, flaxen hair seems to be modeled after another “Harry Potter” bad boy — pure-blood wizard Draco Malfoy.
Some believe that Gowdy and Malfoy may have been separated at birth, with both sporting looks of regret on their faces.
Silas of “The DaVinci Code”
Chip Somodevilla/Getty Images Silas from the movie, "The DaVinci Code," and Gowdy seem to exude a certain sense of pain. Enlarge movieclips/YouTube Silas from the movie, "The DaVinci Code," and Gowdy seem to exude a certain sense of pain. Enlarge Silas from the movie, "The DaVinci Code," and Gowdy seem to exude a sense of pain in certain situations.
The hostile albino monk Silas from the film, “The DaVinci Code,” was popular for flogging himself as punishment for his sins.
Gowdy may not be an albino, monk or show his religious devotion through flagellation like the deranged character, but sometimes sports the same searing look of pain on his face.
Joseph of “Contact”
SAUL LOEB/AFP/Getty Images Chairman Trey Gowdy and religious fanatic Joseph, from the movie "Contact," are zealous in their beliefs. Enlarge Rammshtyn/YouTube Joseph from the film 'Contact' https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RZn825jemqk Enlarge Chairman Trey Gowdy and religious fanatic Joseph, from the movie "Contact," are zealous in their beliefs.
Gowdy was once known for having longer hair — but if it grew any longer, he could have been a dead ringer for the religious fanatic Joseph in “ Contact .”
Gordon Gekko of “Wall Street” and “Wall Street: Money Never Sleeps”
Cliff Owen/AP Tea partyer Trey Gowdy and Gordon Gekko are two men just trying to handle business. Enlarge HO/REUTERS Actor Michael Douglas is shown in his role as Gordon Gekko from the 1987 Oliver Stone film "Wall Street" in this publicity photo released to Reuters September 15, 2009. Twenty-two years after appearing on the big screen, and one year after the collapse of investment bank Lehman Brothers, the film character Gordon Gekko continues to resonate on Wall Street. The "strip and flip" corporate raider played by Michael Douglas will make his comeback in Oliver Stone's "Wall Street 2," which began filming in New York this week. The sequel is set in 2008 during the run-up to the financial meltdown with Gekko emerging from two decades behind bars. To match feature LEHMAN/GEKKO. Similar to the gel-slicked hair and swagger of Gordon Gekko in these famous Oliver Stone film and its sequel — Trey Gowdy means business.
